subject: RE: [junit] Re: ANN: "Unit Testing in Java" available
msgSnippet: Actually I bought and read through it and it is not a very good book. Actually let me qualify that. It is not a good book unless you are heavily into EJB. It
messageBody:
Actually I bought and read through it and it is not a very good
book. Actually let me qualify that. It is not a good book unless
you are heavily into EJB. It angles itself towards EJB using
several different tools; however in each case you just get started
and it jumps topics. So in that sense it is an intro book - just a
bit too much intro and not enough meat (using the word mastering is
just a cruel joke).

A more correct title would have been "EJB using XP and Open Source
Tools".

A very disappointing book.


Chip
-----
Programming: Its not just a job - its an indenture


-----Original Message-----
From: Curt [mailto:ccrandall77@...]
Sent: Wednesday, June 04, 2003 5:13 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: ANN: "Unit Testing in Java" available


Great. I had B&N order one last night so I could look it over. Is
there a table of contents available for it somewhere? I checked a
handful of sites and the description was a little vague. Just
wondering how in-depth it covers JUnit and if it touches on Ant,
Cactus, JUnitPref, HttpUnit, etc.

Has anyone read "Java Tools for Extreme Programming: Mastering Open
Source Tools, including Ant, JUnit, and Cactus"? If so, any
opinions? I read through it briefly and it seemed like a good intro
book.

Thanks,
Curt

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Ilja Preuss" <preuss@d...> wrote:
> > > My book "Unit Testing in Java - How Tests Drive the Code" is
now
> > > available, although Amazon still says it is not:
> > > http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1558608680
>
> Congratulations! :)
>
> Ilja
